thinking.disposable_income: Greater Heights residents have relatively high disposable income with median household income around $110,000, indicating capacity to absorb moderate transportation cost increases.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: The neighborhood has high discretionary spending power evidenced by numerous boutique shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues, suggesting residents can manage higher taxes and fees.
thinking.accessibility: The area has good road access but limited transit options, with most residents relying on cars despite being relatively close to downtown, though some bus routes serve the area.
thinking.decision_rationale: 1) Given high car dependency but desire for better transit, prioritized policies with moderate driving fees to fund transit improvements while keeping taxes reasonable. 2) Selected options that balance travel time improvements with moderate cost increases, as residents can afford some added costs. 3) Favored proposals with lower transit fares to encourage transit use while maintaining service quality. 4) Considered that higher sales tax would affect the area's vibrant retail sector. 5) Prioritized options that reduce car travel times to benefit the car-dependent majority while improving transit service.
